questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a severe headache for 1 hour. Every day of the past week, he has experienced 3–4 episodes of severe pain over his left forehead. Each episode lasts around 30–45 minutes, and he reports pacing around restlessly during these episodes. He has been using acetaminophen for these episodes, but it has provided only minimal relief. He works as a financial analyst and says his job is very stressful. He had experienced similar symptoms 4 months ago but did not seek treatment at that time. He has no history of serious illness and takes no other medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 7 years. He appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is conjunctival injection and tearing of the left eye. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is most likely to provide acute relief of this patient's headaches?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin is not effective in the treatment of cluster headaches. Instead, indomethacin is highly effective in preventing attacks of paroxysmal hemicrania, a rare form of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia, although it is not very effective as an abortive therapy in acute cases. In fact, most treatment options for paroxysmal hemicrania have limited efficacy as abortive therapy. While paroxysmal hemicrania may present very similarly, the attacks are usually more frequent (≥ 5 per day) and often shorter.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose steroid therapy is the treatment of choice for giant cell arteritis (GCA). Patients with GCA can present with severe unilateral headache, as seen in this patient. However, autonomic symptoms do not occur, and symptoms such as jaw claudication and scalp tenderness, which are not seen in this patient, are usually present. More importantly, GCA usually occurs in elderly individuals (peak incidence: 70–79 years) and is rare in patients younger than 50.
Image Description:

Certain pain characteristics and associated symptoms can help in the diagnosis of a secondary headache:

– Temporal arteritis: unilateral headache, jaw claudication, tenderness of scalp or temporal artery, constitutional symptoms, visual changes
– Hypertensive crisis: diffuse, often bifrontal, headache (Headache in the setting of hypertensive crisis can be an isolated finding but may also be a manifestation of hypertensive encephalopathy, which constitutes a hypertensive emergency)
– Sinusitis: Facial pain or pressure in the sinus cavity region, purulent rhinorrhea, flu-like symptoms
– Medication overuse headache: diffuse headache that can change in type and location within an episode and has developed or worsened with pain medication overuse

C) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline is used to prevent chronic tension-type headaches and migraine attacks. Amitriptyline is not used, however, to acutely treat any type of headache.

D) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine is the drug of choice for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia. While trigeminal neuralgia can present with unilateral facial pain that occurs in repetitive attacks, unlike in this patient, these attacks usually only last a few seconds and are characterized by shooting or stabbing pain (like an electric shock) from mouth to the angle of the jaw on the affected side. Frontal headache, conjunctival injection, and lacrimation are not features of trigeminal neuralgia.
Image Description:

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by attacks of facial pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. Classical trigeminal neuralgia is caused by neurovascular compression, most often by an aberrant loop of a neighboring artery (usually the superior cerebellar artery). The pain is typically very severe in intensity, has a sharp, stabbing quality, and lasts several seconds. Attacks can occur without provocation but are sometimes triggered by stimuli such as brushing teeth.

E) INCORRECT:

Oxycodone is an orally administered opiate analgesic that is used to treat chronic and/or severe pain that cannot be managed with NSAIDs. Opiate analgesics should not, however, be used in the management of primary headache disorders because of the risk of opiate dependence.

F) INCORRECT:

Naproxen can be used for pain relief in, e.g., migraine and acute tension-type headaches (TTH). While TTH are the most common type of primary headache, the pain associated with TTH is usually holocephalic or bifrontal rather than unilateral. Cranial autonomic symptoms, as seen in this patient, do not occur. Migraine is another common type of primary headache disorder that is characterized by episodes of (typically unilateral) headache lasting 4–72 hours accompanied or preceded by nausea, vomiting, hyperacusis, photophobia, and/or aura, which are absent in this patient. Furthermore, while patients with migraine headache tend to rest motionlessly in a quiet, dark room, this patient prefers to pace around during the episodes of pain.

G) CORRECT:

Administration of 100% oxygen is effective in terminating acute episodes of cluster headache in up to 80% of individuals. The exact mechanism is unknown, but it is thought to involve the vasoconstriction of cranial blood vessels in response to high oxygen concentration and hypocapnea.

Sumatriptan and ergotamine are also used to treat cluster headaches, but these drugs should be used with caution because they can cause vasoconstriction; most patients with cluster headaches (approx. 80%) smoke cigarettes and may therefore have other smoking-associated diseases, such as hypertension, peripheral artery disease, and/or coronary artery disease.
questions.hint: This young man has recurrent attacks of severe unilateral headache that are associated with ipsilateral cranial autonomic symptoms (conjunctival injection, lacrimation), which is indicative of cluster headache.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of repeated episodes of severe headache for the past 3 days. He is currently having his 2nd episode of the day. He usually has his first episode in the mornings. The pain is severe and localized to his right forehead and right eye. He had similar symptoms last summer. He works as an analyst for a large hedge fund management company and spends the majority of his time at the computer. He has been under a lot of stress because of overdue paperwork. He also has chronic shoulder pain. He has been using indomethacin every 6 hours for the past 3 days but has had no pain relief. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. He appears restless. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows drooping of the right eyelid, tearing of the right eye, and rhinorrhea. The right pupil is 2 mm and the left pupil is 4 mm. There is localized tenderness to his right supraspinatus muscle. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trigeminal neuralgia presents with a paroxysmal and unilateral severe stabbing pain along distribution of the trigeminal nerve. Episodes last several seconds to minutes and occur repeatedly over the course of a day. Although this patient presents with episodic, severe unilateral pain, the duration of his symptoms is inconsistent. In addition, trigeminal neuralgia cannot explain his rhinorrhea, lacrimation, ptosis, and anisocoria.

B) INCORRECT:

Migraine headaches classically present with unilateral, pulsating, and throbbing pain associated with nausea and sensitivity to bright light and loud sounds. Symptoms are exacerbated by physical activity and symptom duration is typically 4–24 hours. This patient presents with a unilateral headache and has had recent emotional stress, which is a potential trigger for migraine headaches. However, migraines would not explain his rhinorrhea, lacrimation, ptosis, and anisocoria.

C) CORRECT:

Cluster headaches are characterized by 15-minute to 3-hour episodes of severe, unilateral pain, often behind or around one eye. The condition is more common in men and often occurs around the same time each day. Cluster headaches frequently have a cyclical pattern with periods of months to years without symptoms in between episodes, as seen here. Associated symptoms include ipsilateral autonomic symptoms, such as lacrimation and rhinorrhea. Pupillary changes, which are also seen in this patient, may occur as part of a partial Horner syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Giant cell arteritis classically presents with a unilateral headache with throbbing synchronously to the pulse of the temporal artery. Patients may present with jaw claudication, constitutional symptoms, or loss of vision due to ophthalmic artery occlusion. Giant cell arteritis is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica, a condition characterized by pain and stiffness of the shoulder and hip girdles. Although this patient presents with unilateral headache and chronic shoulder pain, he lacks other key findings to support this diagnosis. In addition, giant cell arteritis is rarely seen in individuals < 50 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

A subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) classically presents with acute onset, excruciating pain (thunderclap headache) that spreads over the entire head and can be associated with meningism, impaired level of consciousness, and focal neurological findings. Although this patient presents with headache and neurologic findings (ptosis and anisocoria), the fluctuating and unilateral nature of his symptoms are inconsistent with SAH. In addition, SAH would not explain his rhinorrhea and lacrimation.

F) INCORRECT:

Tension headaches are characterized by episodic, dull, holocranial or bifrontal pain that is mild to moderate in intensity. Although this patient has risk factors for tension headaches, such as stress and anxiety, the severe and unilateral nature of his symptoms is inconsistent with this diagnosis. In addition, tension headache would not explain his rhinorrhea, lacrimation, ptosis, and anisocoria.

G) INCORRECT:

Medication overuse headaches (MOH) are caused by frequent use of analgesics (typically ≥ 10 days/month for > 3 months). They manifest as daily headaches that typically occur upon awakening. Although this patient has morning headaches in the setting of analgesic use, he has only been using indomethacin for the past 3 days, making MOH an unlikely cause of his headaches. Furthermore, MOH would not explain his rhinorrhea, lacrimation, ptosis, and anisocoria.
Image Description:

Certain pain characteristics and associated symptoms can help in the diagnosis of a secondary headache:

– Temporal arteritis: unilateral headache, jaw claudication, tenderness of scalp or temporal artery, constitutional symptoms, visual changes
– Hypertensive crisis: diffuse, often bifrontal, headache (Headache in the setting of hypertensive crisis can be an isolated finding but may also be a manifestation of hypertensive encephalopathy, which constitutes a hypertensive emergency)
– Sinusitis: Facial pain or pressure in the sinus cavity region, purulent rhinorrhea, flu-like symptoms
– Medication overuse headache: diffuse headache that can change in type and location within an episode and has developed or worsened with pain medication overuse
questions.hint: This type of headache comes in acute attacks that can be aborted using high-flow supplemental oxygen.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department for 2 days of episodic headaches. The pain is most intense on his left forehead and eye. He had similar symptoms last summer. He has been taking indomethacin every 6 hours for the last 24 hours but has not had any relief. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 5 years. He works as an accountant and describes his work as very stressful. He appears restless. Physical examination shows drooping of the left eyelid, tearing of the left eye, and rhinorrhea. The left pupil is 2 mm and the right pupil is 4 mm. There is localized tenderness along the right supraspinatus muscle. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Giant cell arteritis (GCA) is a rheumatic disorder that can present with a unilateral headache, jaw claudication, and amaurosis fugax. This patient's age, lacrimation, miosis, and rhinorrhea are more consistent with a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) classically manifests with an acute, holocephalic, excruciating headache ("thunderclap headache") and is most commonly caused by the rupture of intracranial aneurysms. Although smoking is a known risk factor for SAH and patients can present with various neurological findings (including miosis), this patient does not have other important clinical signs of SAH (e.g., meningism, altered consciousness) and has had symptoms for 2 days. Moreover, neither conjunctival symptoms nor rhinorrhea is consistent with SAH.

C) INCORRECT:

Medication overuse headache (MOH) typically manifests as a dull, long-lasting headache in the setting of regular use of headache medication (defined as ≥ 10 days per month for ≥ 3 months). The patient's acute indomethacin use is not long enough to induce MOH. Furthermore, MOH is associated with nausea but would not explain the lacrimation or rhinorrhea seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Certain pain characteristics and associated symptoms can help in the diagnosis of a secondary headache:

– Temporal arteritis: unilateral headache, jaw claudication, tenderness of scalp or temporal artery, constitutional symptoms, visual changes
– Hypertensive crisis: diffuse, often bifrontal, headache (Headache in the setting of hypertensive crisis can be an isolated finding but may also be a manifestation of hypertensive encephalopathy, which constitutes a hypertensive emergency)
– Sinusitis: Facial pain or pressure in the sinus cavity region, purulent rhinorrhea, flu-like symptoms
– Medication overuse headache: diffuse headache that can change in type and location within an episode and has developed or worsened with pain medication overuse

D) CORRECT:

Cluster headache is characterized by agonizing, unilateral periorbital or temporal pain. It is more common in men and attacks are commonly accompanied by lacrimation and rhinorrhea. Pupillary changes can be seen as part of partial Horner syndrome (no decreased vision). Cluster headache does not respond to NSAIDs but is treated with oxygen and triptans.

E) INCORRECT:

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by a paroxysmal, severe shooting headache affecting the distribution of the trigeminal nerve that may be triggered by certain movements (e.g., talking). Trigeminal neuralgia is typically unilateral but is not associated with lacrimation or rhinorrhea.
Image Description:

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by attacks of facial pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. Classical trigeminal neuralgia is caused by neurovascular compression, most often by an aberrant loop of a neighboring artery (usually the superior cerebellar artery). The pain is typically very severe in intensity, has a sharp, stabbing quality, and lasts several seconds. Attacks can occur without provocation but are sometimes triggered by stimuli such as brushing teeth.

F) INCORRECT:

A migraine is characterized as a recurrent pulsating and throbbing headache that lasts multiple hours or days and is usually unilateral. Migraine is typically associated with nausea, photophobia, and hypersensitivity to sound, and is exacerbated by exercise, none of which is seen in this patient. Furthermore, migraine headaches do not manifest with rhinorrhea, lacrimation, or miosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Tension headaches are characterized by episodic, mild to moderate, non-pulsating, dull, holocranial or bifrontal headaches. Although risk factors include stress, tension headaches are not usually unilateral and do not present with lacrimation or rhinorrhea. Moreover, tension headaches are relieved with NSAIDs.
questions.hint: This headache can be aborted by administering 100% oxygen.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of an excruciating headache that started 30 minutes ago. The pain is located around the right eye and it awoke him from sleep. Over the past two weeks, he has had similar headaches around the same time of the day, and he reports pacing around restlessly during these episodes. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and tearing of the right eye. In addition to supplemental oxygen therapy, administration of which of the following drugs is most likely to provide acute relief in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin is highly effective in preventing attacks of paroxysmal hemicrania (PH), a rare form of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia, but not very effective as an abortive therapy in acute cases. While PH may present very similarly, the attacks are usually more frequent (≥ 5 per day) and often shorter. In cluster headache, NSAIDs like indomethacin are generally not recommended because their onset of action is too slow.

B) CORRECT:

Triptans like sumatriptan are the first-line pharmacological treatment for acute attacks of cluster headache. They abort the headache and provide resolution of the conjunctival injection associated with these attacks. The exact mechanism is unclear, but it is thought to involve the vasoconstriction of cranial blood vessels in response to stimulation of 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) receptors. Inhalation of 100% oxygen is also effective in terminating acute episodes of cluster headache and has a rapid onset of action.

Triptans are also the treatment of choice for severe migraine attacks.

C) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs like ibuprofen can be used for pain relief in, e.g. mild to moderate migraine attacks or acute tension-type headaches (TTH). While the pain associated with TTH is usually holocephalic or bifrontal, and cranial autonomic symptoms, as seen in this patient, do not occur; migraine is characterized by episodes of typically unilateral headache lasting 4–72 hours accompanied or preceded by nausea, phono- and photophobia, and/or aura, which are absent in this patient. Furthermore, while patients with migraine tend to rest motionlessly in a quiet, dark room, this patient prefers to pace around during the episodes of pain.

D) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine is the drug of choice for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia. While trigeminal neuralgia can present with unilateral facial pain that occurs in repetitive attacks, unlike in this patient, these attacks usually only last a few seconds and are characterized by shooting or stabbing pain (like an electric shock) from mouth to the angle of the jaw on the affected side. Frontal headache, conjunctival injection, rhinorrhea, and lacrimation are not features of trigeminal neuralgia.
Image Description:

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by attacks of facial pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. Classical trigeminal neuralgia is caused by neurovascular compression, most often by an aberrant loop of a neighboring artery (usually the superior cerebellar artery). The pain is typically very severe in intensity, has a sharp, stabbing quality, and lasts several seconds. Attacks can occur without provocation but are sometimes triggered by stimuli such as brushing teeth.

E) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline is used to prevent chronic tension-type headaches and migraine attacks. Amitriptyline is not used, however, to acutely treat any type of headache.

F) INCORRECT:

High-dose steroid therapy is the treatment of choice for giant cell arteritis (GCA), which can present with severe unilateral headache, as seen in this patient. However, autonomic symptoms do not occur, and symptoms such as jaw claudication and scalp tenderness, which are not seen in this patient, are usually present. More importantly, GCA usually occurs in elderly individuals (peak incidence: 70–79 years) and is rare in patients younger than 50.

Prednisone can be used as a preventive treatment for cluster headache; however, this patient with an acute presentation needs an abortive therapy.
Image Description:

Certain pain characteristics and associated symptoms can help in the diagnosis of a secondary headache:

– Temporal arteritis: unilateral headache, jaw claudication, tenderness of scalp or temporal artery, constitutional symptoms, visual changes
– Hypertensive crisis: diffuse, often bifrontal, headache (Headache in the setting of hypertensive crisis can be an isolated finding but may also be a manifestation of hypertensive encephalopathy, which constitutes a hypertensive emergency)
– Sinusitis: Facial pain or pressure in the sinus cavity region, purulent rhinorrhea, flu-like symptoms
– Medication overuse headache: diffuse headache that can change in type and location within an episode and has developed or worsened with pain medication overuse

G) INCORRECT:

Oxycodone is an orally administered opiate analgesic that is used to treat chronic and/or severe pain that cannot be managed with NSAIDs. Opiate analgesics should not, however, be used in the management of primary headache disorders because of the risk of opiate dependence.
questions.hint: This young man has recurrent attacks of severe unilateral headache that are associated with ipsilateral cranial autonomic symptoms (conjunctival injection, lacrimation), which is indicative of cluster headache.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man reports a 4-year history of excruciating headaches that recur daily for 2 to 3 weeks each spring. During these periods, he experiences episodes of stabbing pain in the left orbital and temporal region 1 to 2 times per day. Each attack lasts 45 to 90 minutes and is associated with left-sided conjunctival redness, nasal congestion, and lacrimation. He is unable to sleep or even lie down to rest during these attacks.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient when his headaches occur?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the presentation of paroxysmal hemicrania is very similar to that of cluster headache (recurrent unilateral pain, conjunctival injection, lacrimation, and nasal stuffiness or congestion), the duration of a headache attack in paroxysmal hemicrania tends to be shorter (lasting 2 to 30 minutes), and number of attacks per day is higher (up to 12 during a flare). Paroxysmal hemicrania occurs more frequently in women than men. By definition, paroxysmal hemicranias are responsive to indomethacin.

B) INCORRECT:

Propranolol can be used as preventive medications for selected patients with migraine. It is not typically used for abortive or preventive treatment of cluster headaches.

C) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (e.g., naproxen) can be used as preventive medications for selected patients with migraine. These drugs are not typically used for abortive or preventive treatment of cluster headaches.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is most consistent with cluster headache. Most patients with cluster headaches experience 1 to 2 headache attacks daily, but the pattern can vary from every other day to 8 times per day. The attacks can last from 15 minutes to 3 hours and tend to recur at the same time of day. Cluster headaches are often episodic, with remission and recurrence sometimes timed with the seasons. The most effective acute abortive treatment options for cluster headaches include sumatriptan (by injection or nasal administration) or 100% high-flow oxygen (administered at 10 to 15 liters per minute for 15 to 30 minutes). Verapamil is the drug of choice for preventive therapy.

Key learning point: The most effective acute abortive treatment for cluster headache is 100% oxygen or sumatriptan.

E) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline can be used as preventive medications for selected patients with migraine. It is not typically used for abortive or preventive treatment of cluster headaches.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents for evaluation of a recurring headache that he describes as a stabbing sensation behind his left eye. The headaches have occurred once or twice daily for the past 7 days, with each one lasting 15 to 30 minutes. The patient reports excessive tearing and nasal congestion on the left side during these attacks but no photophobia, prodrome, nausea, or vomiting. He cannot identify any inciting events.
During the visit, the patient experiences one of these attacks. Miosis is noted on the left side. There is no tenderness to palpation along the scalp or neck. A comprehensive neurologic examination is normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary stabbing headaches are characterized by transient, sharp pains in a small, localized area of the scalp within the first division of the trigeminal nerve. Unlike cluster headaches, primary stabbing headaches have no associated cranial autonomic symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's history is consistent with cluster headache. Cluster headache is diagnosed clinically based on the occurrence of at least five attacks that (a) last 15 to 180 minutes each; (b) are characterized by severe unilateral pain in the orbital, supraorbital, and/or temporal region; and (c) are accompanied by at least one autonomic sign or symptom ipsilateral to the headache, a sense of restlessness or agitation, or both. To meet diagnostic criteria, the attacks must occur at least once every other day and up to eight times daily for more than half the time that the disorder is active.

Key learning point: The occurrence of five or more attacks of a severe unilateral orbital headache with associated prominent autonomic symptoms but no prodrome or photophobia is most consistent with cluster headache.

C) INCORRECT:

Migraines manifest similarly to cluster headaches, but the lack of prodrome or photophobia in this patient’s history makes migraine a less likely diagnosis in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Tension-type headaches are primarily muscular, manifesting with a classic band of pain around the head. The symptoms can be reproduced with palpation, are often bilateral, and are not associated with autonomic symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Isolated trigeminal neuralgia is also unilateral, but it manifests with brief, severely painful episodes in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (at the temple, at the temporomandibular joint, and down the side of the face along the jaw). Its distribution is thus different from that of a cluster headache. Trigeminal neuralgia may coexist with cluster headaches.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents for evaluation of a recurring headache that he describes as a stabbing sensation behind his left eye. The headaches have occurred once or twice daily for the past 7 days, with each one lasting 15 to 30 minutes. The patient reports excessive tearing and nasal congestion on the left side during these attacks but no photophobia, prodrome, nausea, or vomiting. He cannot identify any inciting events.
During the visit, the patient experiences one of these attacks. Miosis is noted on the left side. There is no tenderness to palpation along the scalp or neck. A comprehensive neurologic examination is normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary stabbing headaches are characterized by transient, sharp pains in a small, localized area of the scalp within the first division of the trigeminal nerve. Unlike cluster headaches, primary stabbing headaches have no associated cranial autonomic symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Tension-type headaches are primarily muscular, manifesting with a classic band of pain around the head. The symptoms can be reproduced with palpation, are often bilateral, and are not associated with autonomic symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Migraines manifest similarly to cluster headaches, but the lack of prodrome or photophobia in this patient’s history makes migraine a less likely diagnosis in this case.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's history is consistent with cluster headache. Cluster headache is diagnosed clinically based on the occurrence of at least five attacks that (a) last 15 to 180 minutes each; (b) are characterized by severe unilateral pain in the orbital, supraorbital, and/or temporal region; and (c) are accompanied by at least one autonomic sign or symptom ipsilateral to the headache, a sense of restlessness or agitation, or both. To meet diagnostic criteria, the attacks must occur at least once every other day and up to eight times daily for more than half the time that the disorder is active.

Key learning point: The occurrence of five or more attacks of a severe unilateral orbital headache with associated prominent autonomic symptoms but no prodrome or photophobia is most consistent with cluster headache.

E) INCORRECT:

Isolated trigeminal neuralgia is also unilateral, but it manifests with brief, severely painful episodes in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (at the temple, at the temporomandibular joint, and down the side of the face along the jaw). Its distribution is thus different from that of a cluster headache. Trigeminal neuralgia may coexist with cluster headaches.

He has been taking indomethacin every 6 hours for the last 24 hours but has not had any relief. He works as an accountant and describes his work as very stressful. Physical examination shows drooping of the left eyelid, tearing of the left eye, and rhinorrhea. The left pupil is 2 mm and the right pupil is 4 mm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A) INCORRECT:

Giant cell arteritis (GCA) is a rheumatic disorder that can present with a unilateral headache, jaw claudication, and amaurosis fugax. This patient's age, lacrimation, miosis, and rhinorrhea are more consistent with a different diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

Cluster headache is characterized by agonizing, unilateral periorbital or temporal pain. It is more common in men and attacks are commonly accompanied by lacrimation and rhinorrhea. Pupillary changes can be seen as part of partial Horner syndrome (no decreased vision). Cluster headache does not respond to NSAIDs but is treated with oxygen and triptans.

C) INCORRECT:

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by a paroxysmal, severe shooting headache affecting the distribution of the trigeminal nerve that may be triggered by certain movements (e.g., talking). Trigeminal neuralgia is typically unilateral but is not associated with lacrimation or rhinorrhea.
Image Description:

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by attacks of facial pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. Classical trigeminal neuralgia is caused by neurovascular compression, most often by an aberrant loop of a neighboring artery (usually the superior cerebellar artery). The pain is typically very severe in intensity, has a sharp, stabbing quality, and lasts several seconds. Attacks can occur without provocation but are sometimes triggered by stimuli such as brushing teeth.

D) INCORRECT:

A migraine is characterized as a recurrent pulsating and throbbing headache that lasts multiple hours or days and is usually unilateral. Migraine is typically associated with nausea, photophobia, and hypersensitivity to sound, and is exacerbated by exercise, none of which is seen in this patient. Furthermore, migraine headaches do not manifest with rhinorrhea, lacrimation, or miosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Tension headaches are characterized by episodic, mild to moderate, non-pulsating, dull, holocranial or bifrontal headaches. Although risk factors include stress, tension headaches are not usually unilateral and do not present with lacrimation or rhinorrhea. Moreover, tension headaches are relieved with NSAIDs.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man reports a 4-year history of excruciating headaches that recur daily for 2 to 3 weeks each spring. During these periods, he experiences episodes of stabbing pain in the left orbital and temporal region 1 to 2 times per day. Each attack lasts 45 to 90 minutes and is associated with left-sided conjunctival redness, nasal congestion, and lacrimation. He is unable to sleep or even lie down to rest during these attacks. Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient when his headaches occur?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the presentation of paroxysmal hemicrania is very similar to that of cluster headache (recurrent unilateral pain, conjunctival injection, lacrimation, and nasal stuffiness or congestion), the duration of a headache attack in paroxysmal hemicrania tends to be shorter (lasting 2 to 30 minutes), and number of attacks per day is higher (up to 12 during a flare). Paroxysmal hemicrania occurs more frequently in women than men. By definition, paroxysmal hemicranias are responsive to indomethacin.

B) INCORRECT:

Propranolol can be used as preventive medications for selected patients with migraine. It is not typically used for abortive or preventive treatment of cluster headaches.

C) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (e.g., naproxen) can be used as preventive medications for selected patients with migraine. These drugs are not typically used for abortive or preventive treatment of cluster headaches.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is most consistent with cluster headache. Most patients with cluster headaches experience 1 to 2 headache attacks daily, but the pattern can vary from every other day to 8 times per day. The attacks can last from 15 minutes to 3 hours and tend to recur at the same time of day. Cluster headaches are often episodic, with remission and recurrence sometimes timed with the seasons. The most effective acute abortive treatment options for cluster headaches include sumatriptan (by injection or nasal administration) or 100% high-flow oxygen (administered at 10 to 15 liters per minute for 15 to 30 minutes). Verapamil is the drug of choice for preventive therapy.

Key learning point: The most effective acute abortive treatment for cluster headache is 100% oxygen or sumatriptan.

E) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline can be used as preventive medications for selected patients with migraine. It is not typically used for abortive or preventive treatment of cluster headaches.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man presents with excruciating left-sided periorbital headaches that have recurred daily for the past week, each lasting about 45 minutes and accompanied by tearing, nasal congestion, and partial eyelid droop. He has had similar episodes in previous months, which resolved spontaneously after a few days. Neurological examination is normal between attacks. He is concerned about preventing future headaches.
Which of the following is the most appropriate prophylactic measure for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin is effective for paroxysmal hemicrania, not cluster headaches. Cluster headaches involve hypothalamic and neurovascular dysregulation, which indomethacin's cyclooxygenase inhibition does not address.

B) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant, is used for migraine and chronic tension-type headache prophylaxis but lacks efficacy in cluster headache prevention. Cluster headaches involve hypothalamic dysfunction and trigeminal autonomic dysregulation, which amitriptyline does not address.

C) INCORRECT:

Propranolol, a nonselective beta-adrenergic blocker, is effective for migraine prophylaxis but not for cluster headaches. Cluster headaches involve hypothalamic activation and parasympathetic hyperactivity, which are not modulated by beta-adrenergic blockade.

D) CORRECT:

Cluster headaches manifest with severe unilateral periorbital pain and ipsilateral autonomic symptoms, such as lacrimation and nasal congestion. Verapamil, a calcium channel blocker, is the preferred prophylactic treatment for cluster headaches. It modulates neurovascular mechanisms and stabilizes neuronal excitability within the trigeminal-autonomic reflex pathway. Verapamil reduces the frequency and intensity of headache clusters. Careful dose titration and monitoring, including baseline and periodic electrocardiograms, are necessary due to the risk of cardiac conduction abnormalities.

Key learning point: Verapamil is the first-line preventive treatment for cluster headaches, which are characterized by severe, unilateral headaches with autonomic symptoms.

questions.text: You are seeing a 23-year-old man in the emergency department with a 2-day history of episodic headaches. The pain is most severe over his left forehead and eye. He has been taking indomethacin every 6 hours for the past 24 hours without relief. He works as an accountant and describes his job as very stressful. On examination, he has left eyelid drooping, tearing of the left eye, and rhinorrhea. The left pupil measures 2 mm and the right pupil 4 mm. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cluster headache is characterized by agonizing, unilateral periorbital or temporal pain. It is more common in men and attacks are commonly accompanied by lacrimation and rhinorrhea. Pupillary changes can be seen as part of partial Horner syndrome (no decreased vision). Cluster headache does not respond to NSAIDs but is treated with oxygen and triptans.

Key learning point: Cluster headache presents as severe, unilateral periorbital pain with autonomic symptoms such as lacrimation, rhinorrhea, and partial Horner syndrome, and is best treated with oxygen or triptans rather than NSAIDs.

B) INCORRECT:

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by a paroxysmal, severe shooting headache affecting the distribution of the trigeminal nerve that may be triggered by certain movements (e.g., talking). Trigeminal neuralgia is typically unilateral but is not associated with lacrimation or rhinorrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

A migraine is characterized as a recurrent pulsating and throbbing headache that lasts multiple hours or days and is usually unilateral. Migraine is typically associated with nausea, photophobia, and hypersensitivity to sound, and is exacerbated by exercise, none of which is seen in this patient. Furthermore, migraine headaches do not manifest with rhinorrhea, lacrimation, or miosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Tension headaches are characterized by episodic, mild to moderate, non-pulsating, dull, holocranial or bifrontal headaches. Although risk factors include stress, tension headaches are not usually unilateral and do not present with lacrimation or rhinorrhea. Moreover, tension headaches are relieved with NSAIDs.

E) INCORRECT:

Giant cell arteritis (GCA) is a rheumatic disorder that can present with a unilateral headache, jaw claudication, and amaurosis fugax. This patient's age, lacrimation, miosis, and rhinorrhea are more consistent with a different diagnosis.
questions.hint: This headache can be aborted by administering 100% oxygen.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 4-year history of severe headaches that recur daily for 2 to 3 weeks each spring. During these periods, he experiences episodes of stabbing pain in the left orbital and temporal region 1 to 2 times per day. Each attack lasts 45 to 90 minutes and is associated with left-sided conjunctival redness, nasal congestion, and lacrimation. He reports that he is unable to sleep or lie down to rest during these attacks. Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for him when his headaches occur?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin is the treatment of choice for paroxysmal hemicrania. Although the presentation of paroxysmal hemicrania is very similar to that of cluster headache (recurrent unilateral pain, conjunctival injection, lacrimation, and nasal stuffiness or congestion), the duration of a headache attack in paroxysmal hemicrania tends to be shorter (lasting 2 to 30 minutes), and number of attacks per day is higher (up to 12 during a flare). Indomethacin is not typically used in cluster headache.

B) CORRECT:

Most patients with cluster headaches experience 1 to 2 headache attacks daily, but the pattern can vary from every other day to 8 times per day. The attacks can last from 15 minutes to 3 hours and tend to recur at the same time of day. Cluster headaches are often episodic, with remission and recurrence sometimes timed with the seasons. The most effective acute abortive treatment options for cluster headaches include sumatriptan (by injection or nasal administration) or 100% high-flow oxygen (administered at 10 to 15 liters per minute for 15 to 30 minutes). Verapamil is the drug of choice for preventive therapy.

Key learning point: The most effective acute abortive treatment for cluster headache is 100% oxygen or sumatriptan.

C) INCORRECT:

Propranolol can be used as preventive medications for selected patients with migraine. It is not typically used for abortive or preventive treatment of cluster headaches.

D) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline can be used as preventive medications for selected patients with migraine. It is not typically used for abortive or preventive treatment of cluster headaches.

E) INCORRECT:

Lisinopril can be used as a preventive medication for selected patients with migraine. This drug is not typically used for abortive or preventive treatment of cluster headaches.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is most consistent with cluster headache.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with severe right-sided orbital pain that began 45 minutes ago. He appears restless and reports similar episodes occurring daily around the same time for the past 10 days. Physical examination shows right-sided conjunctival injection and lacrimation. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Opioids are ineffective for cluster headache treatment and may lead to medication overuse headache with frequent use. Standard analgesics do not provide adequate pain relief for the severe pain of cluster headaches.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- High-flow oxygen therapy with 100% FiO2 is first-line acute treatment for cluster headache attacks. The oxygen should be administered at 6–12 L/min via a nonrebreather mask for 15–30 minutes with the patient sitting upright. The mechanism of action is unknown, but oxygen provides rapid relief for most patients.

C) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs like ketorolac are not effective for cluster headache attacks. Standard analgesics do not provide adequate relief for cluster headache pain and may contribute to medication overuse headache.

D) INCORRECT:

Acetaminophen is not effective for cluster headache attacks. Standard analgesics do not provide adequate pain relief for the severe pain characteristic of cluster headaches and may lead to medication overuse headache.

E) INCORRECT:

Prednisone is used as transitional therapy in cluster headache prophylaxis, not for acute attack treatment. Prednisone serves as bridge therapy until prophylactic agents become effective but is not appropriate for immediate pain relief during an acute episode.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe left-sided periorbital pain that began suddenly 30 minutes ago. He reports having had similar episodes around the same time last year. Examination shows ipsilateral lacrimation and nasal congestion. Vital signs are BP, 130/80; P, 88; R, 16; T, 36.9°C (98.4°F); SpO₂, 99% on room air. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Subcutaneous sumatriptan is a first-line treatment option for acute cluster headache attacks. Oxygen therapy with FiO2 100% is another first-line option that is usually preferred over triptans when oxygen therapy is available.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral zolmitriptan can be used for cluster headache treatment but is considered second-line therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Intranasal lidocaine may potentially be effective in cluster headache, but has limited evidence to support its use. It is only considered when first-line treatments have not been effective.

D) INCORRECT:

Standard analgesics, including NSAIDs like ketorolac, are not recommended for cluster headache because they are ineffective and may lead to medication overuse headache if used frequently.

E) INCORRECT:

While metoclopramide may be useful for migraine-associated nausea, it is not an established treatment for cluster headache attacks.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a three-week history of recurrent, severe headaches. He describes an excruciating, sharp pain behind his right eye that lasts for approximately 45 minutes. These episodes occur up to twice daily, frequently awakening him from sleep in the early morning hours. During the attacks, he notes right-sided eye redness, tearing, and nasal congestion. He reports feeling intensely restless during the episodes, often pacing his bedroom until the pain subsides. He has a 20-pack-year smoking history. His neurologic examination is nonfocal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for a cluster headache, a type of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia. Key features include the patient's demographic (middle-aged male smoker), the severe, unilateral, retro-orbital pain, and the short duration of attacks (15–180 minutes). The diagnosis is strongly supported by the presence of ipsilateral autonomic symptoms, such as conjunctival injection, lacrimation, and nasal congestion. A pathognomonic feature is the profound sense of restlessness or agitation during an attack, which contrasts with the desire for rest seen in migraine. The cyclical nature and nocturnal awakenings are also characteristic. First-line acute treatment includes 100% oxygen via a non-rebreather mask or subcutaneous sumatriptan.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute angle-closure glaucoma can cause severe unilateral eye pain, redness, and tearing. However, it is an ophthalmologic emergency associated with a rapid rise in intraocular pressure, which would also cause blurred vision, seeing halos around lights, a hazy cornea, and a fixed, mid-dilated pupil on examination. The attacks would not be recurrent and self-resolving in this cyclical pattern.

C) INCORRECT:

Paroxysmal hemicrania is another trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia that manifests with severe, unilateral pain and ipsilateral autonomic symptoms. However, the attacks are much shorter (typically 2–30 minutes) and more frequent (often more than five times per day) than what this patient describes. A defining feature of paroxysmal hemicrania is its absolute and rapid response to indomethacin, which is not a primary treatment for the condition described.

D) INCORRECT:

While trigeminal neuralgia causes severe, unilateral facial pain, the pain is typically described as brief, electric shock-like, or lancinating, lasting only for seconds. The attacks are often triggered by nonpainful stimuli to the face, such as chewing or light touch. This patient's attacks last for 45 minutes and are not described as being triggered by such stimuli. The prominent autonomic features and restlessness are also less characteristic of trigeminal neuralgia.

E) INCORRECT:

Migraine can manifest with severe, unilateral headache and autonomic features. However, migraine attacks typically last much longer (4–72 hours), not 45 minutes. Furthermore, patients with migraines usually experience photophobia and phonophobia, leading them to seek a dark, quiet room for relief. This is the opposite of the intense restlessness and pacing described by this patient. An aura, which is a transient focal neurologic symptom, was also not reported.
questions.hint: The combination of unilateral autonomic symptoms and the patient's behavior during headache attacks is a key feature that distinguishes among headache disorders.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a severe headache that began 30 minutes ago. He describes the pain as an excruciating, stabbing sensation behind his right eye. He has had similar episodes, occurring once or twice daily for the past two weeks, often waking him from sleep. During the attacks, he experiences right-sided tearing, nasal congestion, and eyelid drooping. He appears agitated and is pacing around the examination room. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient's current episode?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The first-line abortive treatment for cluster headache is 100% oxygen inhalation via a non-rebreather mask. This therapy is effective, has a rapid onset of action, and is well tolerated with minimal side effects. The mechanism is thought to involve cerebral vasoconstriction and modulation of neuronal activity in the trigeminocervical complex. Subcutaneous sumatriptan is another first-line abortive option, but high-flow oxygen is often preferred as the initial intervention due to its excellent safety profile.

B) INCORRECT:

Sumatriptan is a first-line abortive therapy for cluster headaches. However, the oral formulation has a slow onset of action, making it unsuitable for the rapid and severe nature of these attacks, which typically peak in minutes. For acute treatment, faster-acting formulations such as subcutaneous injection or intranasal spray are recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Verapamil, a calcium channel blocker, is the first-line prophylactic (preventive) therapy for cluster headaches. It is taken daily during a cluster period to reduce the frequency and severity of future attacks. It has no role as an abortive agent for treating an acute, ongoing episode.

D) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin is a potent nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that is highly effective for other trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias, such as paroxysmal hemicrania and hemicrania continua. However, it is not an effective treatment for acute cluster headaches.

E) INCORRECT:

Although the pain of a cluster headache is excruciating, opioids like morphine are generally not effective for this condition and are not recommended. Their use carries a significant risk of dependence and can contribute to the development of medication overuse headaches, potentially worsening the patient's overall headache burden.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of severe, unilateral periorbital pain accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (tearing, nasal congestion, ptosis) and restlessness is characteristic of cluster headache.
